title: The Circle's Sammie/James almost quit as he'd 'turned into a bully'
text:
The Circle’s ‘Sammie’ plotted to make sure Georgina and Paddy came out on top (Picture: Channel 4)

The Circle’s Sammie had admitted he almost quit the Channel 4 show as he realised he’d ‘turned into a bit of a bully’.

Catfish Sammie – real name James – came third in the controversial reality show after pretending to be a single mother for three weeks of the show.

‘I almost quit,’ he told Metro.co.uk. admitting that it was ‘guilt’ that made his think he ‘was losing’ himself.

‘There was a part with Woody and he opened up to me about having dyslexia, and because I was an influencer and he was at the bottom, I felt like he was just saying that to stay in and I was like “you can’t kid a kid, eff off”.

‘But I was speaking to Sy directly after it and I broke down a little bit because growing up in foster care and stuff, I felt that I didn’t fit in and I would go out of my way to make people feel accepted.

‘I thought he’s only a kid…and I broke down a little bit, I really did. I thought “I’ve turned into a bit of a bully here” but I made amends with him and I looked after him, he was my little brother.’

On Thursday’s penultimate episode, Ella was given her marching orders by demands of The Circle of Trust – aka Sammie/James, who appeared to many to be getting a little drunk with the power of it all.

But James insists that he was never worried about winning the show, and he knew that Paddy and Georgina ‘fully deserved’ to be the final two.

Woody Cook in his apartment at The Circle (Picture: PA)

‘I gave them advice, you can’t tell people how to rate people, but I gave them advice, and I’d worked out where we would be,’ he said.

‘And it worked, that was all about Paddy and Georgina. I’m not sure what was shown there, but that was a selfless act, but as long as they got to the final, two people that fully deserved it, I didn’t care if I got to the final.

James Doran, 26, from Liverpool, who played as single mother ‘Sammie’ (Picture: PA)

‘So getting to the final was a win/win for me, and I promise you now, from the bottom of my heart I knew I hadn’t won when I stepped into that live show, but winning for me was letting Georgina or Paddy win it.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

He added: ‘People who beat the odds, fighters, and it’s not a case that something’s happened and they got over it, they’re going to have to live with that forever and to shine a light on that situation, and give people in that position confidence… I don’t know the stats, but think about how many people with cerebral palsy are going to feel and uplifted.

‘That meant more to me than the £100,000.’

He said he hopes to meet the real Sammie, whose identity he took for the show, and said that he doesn’t ‘think there are any single mums that dislike what I’ve done or disliked me, they understand’.

Paddy Smyth was crowned the winner of The Circle 2019, taking home a huge £70,000, after the remaining contestants’ – Woody, Tim, Georgina, Sammie/James and Paddy – voted for who they wanted to see land the cash prize.

A public vote also decided who would win an additional £30,000, with Tim topping the vote and bagging the prize.

Speaking about winning the show, Paddy said: ‘I’m in complete shock. Honestly I never thought I’d make it past the first blocking.

‘To come in as a late player and come in with such insecurities about myself and to know that Circle accepted me and you guys accepted me, it’s just insane. I didn’t think I’d even get here.’
